compute.name: axona_file
compute.description: Reads an axomna file which consists of a header block of multiple lines of: ``` key_name [SPACE] key_value ``` Followed by a line that begins with the characters `"data_start"`. Following that is a (large) block of binary data. In some cases (set files) there may not be a `data_start` and binary_data section. This compute is aliased as `pos_file`, `set_file`, `tet_file`, and `eeg_file`.

compute.name: both_xy
compute.description: This takes the pos header and buffer and does the pos-post-processing, to produce either 1 or two arrays of points (only 1 if 1 LED was used).

compute.name: xy
compute.description: If there are two LEDs, this takes both sets of XY data and combines them to get a single value of xy for each moment in time. with 1 LED, this simply uses that 1 array of XY data.

compute.name: dir
compute.description: The `used_both` is copied across from both_xy for convenience. If both LEDs are used then `dir!= dir_disp`, otherwise `dir` is `dir_disp`.

compute.name: speed
eeg
compute.description: Simply pulls the eeg data from the file into an array, swapping endian-ness if need be.

input.name: eeg_freq_band_of_interest
input.description: The low and high values in Hz. Theta is often treated as `6-12Hz`.

compute.name: eeg_analytic
compute.description:
Bandpasses the eeg using a [Blackman window](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Window_function#Blackman_windows) and then performs the [hilbert transform](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hilbert_transform) to get a complex (ie. `x +iy`) value for each time point.
Note `timebase` is copied through from `eeg` for convenience.

compute.name: eeg_phase
compute.description:
Simply gives the complex angle of the analytic signal.
Note `timebase` is copied through from `eeg` for convenience.

compute.name: eeg_power
compute.description:
Simply gives the complex magnitude of the analytic signal.
Note `timebase` is copied through from `eeg` for convenience.

compute.name: eeg_power_spectrum
compute.description: Peforms a Fourier transform, probably using the Fast method (unless a particularly small spectral window is needed in which case it might be better to use a naive DFT).

input.name: eeg_total_freq_band
input.description: When computing signal-to-noise we ignore noise outside this range. Specified in Hz.

compute.name: freq_band_sig_to_noise
compute.description: Finds peak in the spectrum, within the `eeg_freq_band_of_interest`. Then computes the energy in the spectrum 1Hz either side of this, and normalizes by the average energy in `eeg_total_freq_band`.

compute.name: dist_to_boundary
pos_mask
compute.description: `True` means use pos, `False` means don't use it. Computes a mask using zero or more of four differnt possible speicifications. Check `summary` to see if the mask is all-`False`, or all-`True`. Note that you might want to have something even more complciated in terms of adding, subtracting and multiple slices. Not sure how easy that would be to implement in any framework, psoup or otherwise...well it might be ok in python actually.

compute.name: speed_dwell
pos_bin_ind
spike_times
compute.description: returns spike times in same units as `tet_file` stored them

compute.name: waves
compute.description:
The wave data for a spike is `50` samples on each of the `4` channels within a tetrode, i.e. `200` samples. Each sample is one byte.
*Optimization note:* we chunk data for 5,000 spikes together, using the serialised shape of the file on disk, i.e. even though the data is 3 dimensional, it is only accessible in 1d form, so we lose little by chunking in the same way...actually that's not quite true when it comes to discarding data, but we'll ignore that for now.

compute.name: wave_amplitude
compute.description:
Simply gives the `max-min` for each channel's spike.
Note we store all the data for each channel contiguously (unlike in the `waves` array).

compute.name: wave_energy
compute.description:
Simply gives the `sum` for each channel's spike...well actually, I can't remember exactly how it's normaly defined.
Note we store all the data for each channel contiguously (unlike in the `waves` array).

input.name: sub_spike_t
input.description: The index on the interval `[0,50)`, giving the time of interest within a spike.

compute.name: wave_v_time_t
compute.description:
Simply indexes into the `waves` as requested by `sub_spike_t`.
Note we store all the data for each channel contiguously (unlike in the `waves` array).

compute.name: spike_pos_inds
compute.code: // read timebases to get factor and apply to spike times

compute.name: spike_mask
compute.code: //lookup spike pos inds in pos mask..use sorted_access_iterator

compute.name: cut_file

input.name: cut_delta
input.description: This is a small `enum` and `union`, specifying what kind of change is being made - `split_v_t`, `merge`, `swap`, or `paint` - and providing the params needed for the given change, i.e. a pair of group numbers for a `swap`/`merge`, or a `sub_spike_t` and threshold values for a `split_v_t`.

chain.name: cut_chain
chain.description:
One of the main usage cases of the program is to modify the cluster assignments, which can be thought of as a bit like drawing stuff in Paint in so far as you use one or more tools to modify a "canvas" and expect to see the changes reflected in that canvas. You also want to be able to undo your actions (with ideally a long undo-stack, rather than just a single stored previous state).
Here, we start with either a blank cut or a cut loaded from file. Each `cut_delta` that is tacked onto the chain provides the modification information which could be a swap, or merge, or split, or transfer.
If you are familiar with `git`-like version control you should have that same picture in your mind when trying to understand this (although the concept of merging is not relevant here). The idea in both scenarious is that you have a branching chain, where each link is defined by a connection to a previous point in the chain plus some patch data. So, if I point you to a particular point in the chain, then you can lookup the full history up to that point, and construct what the "reality" should look like as of that revision, noting that you could have branched multiple times during the chain construciton so there may be a number of equally long chain "heads" I could have chosen to point you at.

compute.name: cut_state
compute.description: On the first iteration of cut_changes_loop it reads from cut_file, on subsequent iterations it reads the pervious version of itself, i.e. cut_changes_loop.old_state. Each iteration of the loop is defined by its cut_delta. This compute applies the delta to the the previous state to produce the current state.

compute.name: group_mask
group_times_unmaksed
compute.code: group_times_unmaksed = copy(spike_times.iter_sorted_inds(cut_state.inds_by_group[group_num]));

compute.name: group_times
group_pos_inds_unmasked
compute.code: group_pos_inds_unmasked = copy(spike_pos_inds.iter_sorted_inds(cut_state.inds_by_group[group_num]));

compute.name: group_pos_inds
tac
group_speed_hist
compute.description: Computes rate in each speed bin, normalises to max of 1, but also provides max rate in Hz.
